A <i>[[theory of conduct]]</i> studies what is right, obligated, permitted, required by duty, and what is more than duty requires. It also studies the opposites of these things: what is wrong, forbidden, denied, and evil. Theories of conduct try to answer questions like: "How should I act, and why?" So theories of conduct debate the ultimate standards of right and wrong -- standards of morality, or moral rules. For example, a familiar moral rule is the "Golden Rule": "Do unto others as you would have them do unto you."

Another area is <i>[[applied ethics]]</i>. It applies ethical theories to particular ethical problems. Most academic ethical problems are about public policy.
